channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Live: Covid-19 updates for Tuesday 18 August
item.description: MPs return for three weeks at Parliament they didn't expect and advocates say a move to make it easier for workers to get sick leave while they wait for a Covid-19 test doesn't go far enough.

item.title: Covid-19: Exhausted lab workers having trouble with demand
item.description: Exhausted lab workers working long hours testing for Covid-19 are warning safety could be compromised if the huge demand continues.

item.title: South Auckland locals hit back against online hate around Covid cases
item.description: Some South Auckland locals are hitting back at online hate directed at the area and its Pasifika community, after a local family was the first to test positive for Covid-19 in the current outbreak.

item.title: Covid-19 leave support scheme not enough, advocates say
item.description: A move to make it easier for workers to get sick leave while they wait for their Covid-19 test is being criticised as not going far enough.

item.title: Phillip John Smith returns to court to appeal conviction
item.description: Prison escapee and sex offender Phillip John Smith is back before the courts today to appeal his conviction for fleeing overseas.

item.title: Auckland Grammar head thrilled with back-to-school decision
item.description: A decision by the government will give principals the option of allowing year 12 and 13 students back to school early for face to face learning during alert level 3.

item.title: Covid-19: Ministry investigating Melbourne-based Americold cases to provide clues on cluster
item.description: Cool store chain Americold says it's impossible Covid-19 came to New Zealand via their freight.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 17 August
item.description: Monday has seen the start of the first full week back in alert level 3 for Auckland, and the impacts of the return of Covid-19 in the community are starting to become more pronounced.

item.title: Police looking at issuing instant fines for rule breakers
item.description: After scenes of crowded parks and public areas in Auckland over the weekend, Police Assistant Commissioner Richard Chambers has told Checkpoint issuing fines could be a possibility.

item.title: Ashley Bloomfield on testing of border staff: 'I don't think there's been a failure'
item.description: The Director-General of Health insists there has been no testing failure at the border regarding Covid-19.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates for 17 August
item.description: Here's all that went down at the start of the week, with the prime minister postponing the election date, new cases of community transmission reported, and a new wage subsidy scheme approved.

item.title: Manutuke School students isolated on veranda after Covid-19 scare
item.description: A school near Gisborne isolated about 60 pupils on a veranda this morning after a Covid-19 scare.

item.title: Nine new Covid-19 cases in community today, Bloomfield confirms
item.description: Director-General of Health Ashley Bloomfield says seven of the new cases are linked to the Auckland cluster, while two are under investigation.

item.title: One dead after light plane crashes near Wellington
item.description: One person has died following a light plane crash on the Kāpiti Coast.

item.title: Covid-19 testing ramps up to fill data gap at Port Taranaki
item.description: Forty-four border-facing workers and contractors at Port Taranaki have been tested for Covid-19 over the past week, but the Taranaki DHB can't provide the number of tests carried out since March.

item.title: Covid-19: Pacific health leader warns of potential for 'wildfire' spread in Pacific community
item.description: Pasifika health leaders fear a 'wildfire' outbreak of Covid-19 in the Pacific community if the government doesn't act fast.

item.title: Former teacher found guilty of five charges of indecent acts on boys
item.description: The jury at the High Court in Auckland found Benjamin Swann guilty of five charges but was unable to reach a verdict on the other five.

item.title: Ngāti Whātua confident Auckland checkpoints are working
item.description: Ngāti Whātua representatives assisting police at the Auckland checkpoints are confident people aren't slipping through with border controls significantly tightened up in the last few days.
